message.raw:
Fixed bug where experiment folder name would be incorrect

If the labscript file name (excluding extension) ended with the letters 'p' or 'y', these letters would be missing from the folder name automatically generated by runmanager for storing experiments. This is because we were using strip('.py') which removes the *list* of characters specified from the end of a string until a character not in the list was found.
For instance the following statements are True:
'exp.py'.strip('.py') == 'ex'
'expyy.ypypp.py'.strip('.py') == 'ex'

message.raw:
fixed bug in restoration of output dir

There were a couple of instance variables that were not being restored correctly (one wasn't even saved) which were preventing the output directory from auto-updating when restoring the runmanager state and also preventing the "reset dir" icon (next to the output directory chooser) from working as expected.

*This issue will persist until you resave the runmanager configuration file.* After this, when you restore the file on *future* days, the output dir will be correctly updated. Unfortunately I can't correct the behaviour unless you do this!

refs #451

message.raw:
fixes #770 (in a better way)

I've modified the solution to #770 by overriding the dictionary class of the dictionary of variables passed to the eval() function. This allows us to trace which globals a particular global depends on. This was particularly important because of the following issue:

Imagine a global that was defined as: 7 if condition else a_list_of_values

In the previous code, the global would be found to depend on a_list_of_values regardless of the state of condition. In the new code, it determines dependencies based on what the eval() function requests access to, and so the dependencies do depend on the state of condition as one would expect.

The only "strange" behaviour now is if you set a global to: list_1 if za_list_of_conditions else list_2
In this case, the global will be added to a zip group with 'za_list_of_conditions' (note that "if za_list_of_conditions" always evaluates to True if it is a non empty list) rather than the more obvious option of adding it to a zip group with 'list_1'. Whether the global is added to a zip group with 'list_1' or 'za_list_of_conditions' depends on the global names (the zip group picked is the last dependency in alphabetical order). You can of course, always override the runmanager defaults yourself if you ever encounter an instance like this!

summary.raw:
fixes #770 (in a better way)

I've modified the solution to #770 by overriding the dictionary class of the dictionary of variables passed to the eval() function. This allows us to trace which globals a particular global depends on. This was particularly important because of the following issue:

Imagine a global that was defined as: 7 if condition else a_list_of_values

In the previous code, the global would be found to depend on a_list_of_values regardless of the state of condition. In the new code, it determines dependencies based on what the eval() function requests access to, and so the dependencies do depend on the state of condition as one would expect.

The only "strange" behaviour now is if you set a global to: list_1 if za_list_of_conditions else list_2
In this case, the global will be added to a zip group with 'za_list_of_conditions' (note that "if za_list_of_conditions" always evaluates to True if it is a non empty list) rather than the more obvious option of adding it to a zip group with 'list_1'. Whether the global is added to a zip group with 'list_1' or 'za_list_of_conditions' depends on the global names (the zip group picked is the last dependency in alphabetical order). You can of course, always override the runmanager defaults yourself if you ever encounter an instance like this!

message.raw:
Added the capability to load/save runmanager state.

Just use the entries located in the File menu!
Will remove the "load runmanager defaults" code Russ wrote from the labconfig file (and associated runmanager code) and make runmanager automatically save/load state on exit/start. Users will also be able to save/load their own configurations independently of this.

Also need to save/load the state of:
* Sort order of globals for each group
* Sort order of files loaded in the "Group" tab
* column sizes for all treeviews

refs #451

message.raw:
fixes #770

* Fixes the bug listed in the previous commit message (changeset:2cc771bb2181) where creating a new global whose value is immediately set to another global that had an expansion type crashed runmanager.
* In fixing this, I have also fixed the issue where creating a global and immediately setting the value to a list of values (linspace, [1,2,3], etc) caused the expansion type to be left blank.

This will only work when you set a global to a list of values and that global does not reference another global
When removing the list of values (outer product) the zip group is not yet removed

message.raw:
Added functionality to load default h5 files and groups (in a particular order)
at startup. The key 'default_global_files' in the [runmanager] section of the
LabConfig file (exp_config) is used. The format for default_global_files is a
dictionary of (h5file, group_list) pairs. The group_list ordering sets the order
of the GroupTabs in runmanager. Alternatively, the string 'All' (or 'all', etc.)
can be used as a dictionary value, in which case all groups will be displayed.
If no list (or None, etc.) are specified, no groups are shown. In any case, all
groups of the files loaded are made active.

Note: paths must be placed in a [DEFAULT] section of the config file if they are
to be used in the [runmanager] section.

When the TreeView/liststore of the GroupTab was reordered:
  * focus_cell function determined the wrong path (row), and the wrong cell
    (in either Value or Units column) attained focus.
  * globals not parsed when editing was cancelled on a Units cell
    (and thus duplicate global names were not detected).

Replaced single instance of gtk-delete button with gtk-remove for consistency.

values.message:
Added functionality to load default h5 files and groups (in a particular order)
at startup. The key 'default_global_files' in the [runmanager] section of the
LabConfig file (exp_config) is used. The format for default_global_files is a
dictionary of (h5file, group_list) pairs. The group_list ordering sets the order
of the GroupTabs in runmanager. Alternatively, the string 'All' (or 'all', etc.)
can be used as a dictionary value, in which case all groups will be displayed.
If no list (or None, etc.) are specified, no groups are shown. In any case, all
groups of the files loaded are made active.

Note: paths must be placed in a [DEFAULT] section of the config file if they are
to be used in the [runmanager] section.

When the TreeView/liststore of the GroupTab was reordered:
  * focus_cell function determined the wrong path (row), and the wrong cell
    (in either Value or Units column) attained focus.
  * globals not parsed when editing was cancelled on a Units cell
    (and thus duplicate global names were not detected).

Replaced single instance of gtk-delete button with gtk-remove for consistency.

message.raw:
Made fetching of globals faster by inline everything into one opening of each hdf5 file instead of reusing the 'get_value', 'get_units' etc functions, each of which requires the file to be opened and closed. This should decrease the number of file openings/closings per globals parsing by a factor probably in the hundreds for a typical set of globals.
Testing will reveal if this was indeed the bottleneck.

message.raw:
a (hopefully temporary) fix for bug #610.
This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

message.raw: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.

message.raw:
Fixed deadlock due to recursively opening an h5 file.
Removed some unnecessary parse_globals_required.set() calls.
h5_lock is not enabled quite yet, just need to get network lock caching so that it isn't a horrible slowdown for normal local use. (The idea with this is to not release the network lock for a short time after the lock is released, such that if it is acquired again by a local thread, it need not go out to the network again to acquire the lock, instead avoiding collisions with local threads via ordinary locks)

message.raw:
Cell highlighting to tell you if a value has been evaluated correctly. Tooltips tell you what they evaluated to, or what the exception was if they failed.
This updating happens asynchronously and currently suffers a deadlock issue if you keep doing things with h5py whilst it's evaluating. I won't fix this with locking (network locking will slow it waaay down and process locking is a bit redundant when we're going to need network locking anyway), rather I'll read the values from the GUI instead of the file. This will decrease the amount of file access such that network locking can be used and not be prohibitively slow (file access is what's taking the majority of the time as it is).
In fact, I plan on making runmanager always read from the GUI, to seriously decrease file access during compilation time. I'll be introducting FileWatcher code to check for changes on disk so that they don't get out of step. Even if I don't (but I will) it's way better than the current situation where a change on disk affects the globals in your runs whilst not affecting the GUI at all!

message.raw:
Added functionality for an 'expansion' settings column to group tabs.
This functionality is presently disabled to prevent clashing with existing globals files which lack expansion settings. It will be re-enabled once the code for choosing sensible default expansion settings is complete. These defaults will be entirely compatible with existing hard coded bahaviour, so there will be complete backward compatibility.
Also added an error message dialog for errors during operations on globals. Previously these were uncaught and caused excepthook errors to show. Whilst everything continued to work fine, and the user was properly informed of the error, I'd rather not use excepthook errors this way, they really should indicate an error that is not part of normal use of the program.
Also removed all magic-number style coding from the GroupTab class. All column indices and repeadedly used strings are now defined as constants within the class. This facilitates adding new columns, and aids readability. I'll do the same to the main class soon.

message.raw:
Changes to how labscript handles initialisation and cleanup.
Since runmanager runs labscripts repeatedly, and labscript does initialisation at import time, we've previously been handling this by reloading labscript every run.
This has caused some nasty interaction with ModuleWatcher which I don't quite understand.
Since this was pretty bad practise anyway, labscript now has explicit init and cleanup functions. Usage is still identical in that initialisation still happens at import time, however there is now the option to supress auto-initialisation by setting labscript_auto_init = False in your __main__ module. runmanager's batch_compiler does this and then calls labscript.labscript_init(h5_file, labscript_file) and labscript.labscript_cleanup() explicitly for every shot it compiles, rather than munging sys.argv and simulating a fresh import.

This seems like a much cleaner solution. A quick test will reveal if this fixes #600 (The ModuleWatcher crash)

message.raw:
Made communication with the subprocess asynchronous. Now the parent process is listening for output and piping it to the output box all the time, not just when compilation is running.
This way the user can see when ModuleWatcher notices that modules need reloading, which otherwise would not have appeared until the next compilation. This is so far the only output that the subprocess should produce when not compiling.

message.raw:
Made an attempt at fixing issue #600.
I think the likely cause of the problem was that h5py, being a wrapper around a nontrivial C library, cannot be safely reloaded.  This is to be contrasted with the Pulseblaster spinapi, which appears
The solution was to import h5py prior to instantiating ModuleWatcher

message.raw: Changes to interface with mise; runmanager now sends many more settings than before. Also the diff button now cannot take focus (it used to not only take focus but take it by default, since it was the only focusable widget in the tab)

message.raw: Added "Diff file" button to compare current sequence_globals with those from existing h5 file (using lyse.Run.get_globals_raw and dict_diff). This currently just prints the output of dict_diff, until I get schooled in GTK popups! Also, it'd be nicer if it kept the globals in the grouped format (i.e. didn't flatten the dictionary of dictionaries) so that a tree view could be used to display the result of the diff, and would be nice to have the option to diff evaluated globals, too.

message.raw:
Fixes #596.
Globals are now able to refer to other globals.
Also, batch_compiler.py now uses a filewatcher.ModuleWatcher to ensure that user modules are reloaded upon subsequent imports when they have been modified.
